comments.text:
+ZxLonelyRangerxZ You said without higher order thinking, which I took to

comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+tSp289 I see , i didn't say animals don't feel pain though . For me i 
think as long as it doesn't have a brain , it doesn't feel pain .
comments.author: ZxLoneRangerxZ

comments.text:
+ZxLonelyRangerxZ Well, it wasn't me talking about plants. I was just 
arguing your statement that animals don't really feel pain. Anything with a 
nervous system feels pain. Plants? I have literally no idea. I know they 
react to signals and have some limited communication. How they percieve 
that though, too abstract.
comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+tSp289 What am i saying is , different people feel things differently . So 
does the plant , there is simply not enough research to simply come up with 
the conclusion that plants do feel . What we are seeing is just a reaction 
of plants to something unfavorable and hence is only doing something to 
counter the issue , like i said not enough evidence yet .
comments.author: ZxLoneRangerxZ

comments.text:
+ZxLonelyRangerxZ Incidentally there are some chemical compounds and 
anaesthetics that do not diminish pain at all, but allow you deal with it 
better by being spaced out. It still hurts like hell though.
comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+ZxLonelyRangerxZ The only people I know who you can kick in the balls is 
statues. Some people have nerve damage, sure. Leprosy causes this, and some 
diseases, most of the  damage comes from people not noticing pain, so they 
keep hurting themselves. These are all exceptions. Why would you imagine 
that it takes sentience to feel pain any more than it takes sentience to 
see light? And before you start thinking about colour perception etc, 
nerves are a lot more simple than rods and cones.
comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+tSp289 I see , but it depends . You can kick some people in the balls and 
they don't feel pain , or how some people are born without ability to feel 
but are able to react to something dangerous . It's not pain to them but 
they know it's not good for them and hence will avoid it . Same thing with 
plants
comments.author: ZxLoneRangerxZ

comments.text:
+ZxLonelyRangerxZ Pain is one of the most basic impulses. Just because 
something isn't capable of higher thought, means nothing for whether it can 
feel pain. Pain is a signal saying 'damage! Make it stop!'. It is an 
intense, urgent negative feeling. Anything with a nervous system can feel 
pain, and it will hurt a jellyfish as much as it will hurt a baby. As for 
plants? Well, I dunno, but your argument sounded very much like the 17th 
century naturalists who marvelled at how lifelike the dog's reaction to 
pain was considering it had no soul and therefore was nothing more than an 
automaton incapable of true feeling. It was nonsense then and it's nonsense 
now. If you have a nervous system, pain is pain.
comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+Daniel Tlach I've read the articles , but some of it isn't very convincing 
. Since plants don't have high order thinking , they can't really feel pain 
can they . Since an animal with only their brain stem on can react to pain 
and carry out basic action but they don't feel it . Though the aspect of 
perceiving and feeling the pain is very real , the subject isn't very well 
studied at least yet of course.
comments.author: ZxLoneRangerxZ

top_comment.text:
What's with people always wanting their food raw? I've never tried it so 
I'm not gonna say it's disgusting, I just find it odd. So many people eat 
their steak and tuna etc when it's red in the middle. Why not just have the 
cooked colour all the way through? Isn't it just mushy when it's raw? You 
never see people doing it with chicken (I know, poultry, but still). ﻿
top_comment.author: cwuzii

comments.text:
+Keanen Ferns
There is no blood in commercial meat. When you buy beef, the red liquid 
that the beef is often packaged with is simply water that has been colored 
red by the protein myoglobin that is found in the muscles.

Blood is muck thicker and darker than the liquid most people think of as 
"blood" and cooks up into a thick black paste.

Also, and this is simply a side note, but blood is perfectly edible and 
many cultures eat it. Black Pudding for example is a sausage served in the 
UK that is made out of pork blood and oatmeal.
comments.author: Elamdri

comments.text:
I have the opposite problem. Everyone in my life likes their meat killed 
twice.
comments.author: Travis Westberg

comments.text: +SwedishKnifeWorkshop What about blood?
comments.author: Keanen Ferns

comments.text:
Its like this: Bread and toast are the same thing ones just cooked. 
 Imagine all the breads in the world (cuts of meat) have only ever been 
served to you as toast.  Both are good, but there's so many more flavors 
and textures you are missing by not trying a different temperature.  Here's 
another thing.  These meats are not "raw".  Even though they appear 
uncooked visually, the fat melts and infuses through the meat as it reaches 
a temperature somewhere over 100 degrees F.  Raw steaks would have gristle 
and sinew that would otherwise be inedible.  Everyone loves the taste of 
brownie batter.  Imagine a brownie that had a nice crispy cakey crust on 
the top, but was batter on the inside, while still maintaining its form. 
 While that's kind of an imaginary example, it's that potential combination 
you are missing out on having all your meats well done.  As far as safety - 
look up safe temperatures for meats.  Every meat carries a potential for 
bacteria but cooking guidelines exist to ensure you can have your meat the 
way you like and still be safe.    Good luck!
comments.author: douglasrmarion

comments.text:
+cwuzii I made a steak tartare not long ago, knife chopped into fine cubes 
(not minced), and they are super chewy at first and melt like butter, 
almost chewy candy sort of texture. I used to be a well-done person, now I 
am happily eating real raw, uncooked beef, so long as I am confident about 
the preparation. You should try food with less doneness, in the good spirit 
of adventure.
comments.author: Nanorisk

comments.text:
With fish and tuna it's much easier to cook it less because the bacteria 
dies quicker. A rare steak has no chance of being harmful if cooked 
properly because it's reached the temperature that's killed all the harmful 
bacterias.

It's simply more juicy. If you cook it all the way through it's going to

comments.author: DerpSpY05

comments.text:
+cwuzii
Raw tuna has a very delicate texture and with some soy and wasabi has 
somewhat of a meatiness to it that to me is sorta reminiscent of beef. Two 
things to remember is 1: The odds of getting sick from properly handled, 
raw fish is very, very low. 2: Bacteria doesn't really penetrate into meat. 
It's all on the surface, and it get's killed by the sear. This is why it's 
safe to eat a lot of meats on the rare side. This is ALSO why you must cook 
ground meat well, because the grinding process mixes up the meat so that 
all of it is coated by bacteria,+ whatever was in the machine.

comments.author: norcatch

comments.text:
+norcatch Great recommendation.  Although I'd say to be careful with this 
method.  Tuna, Poultry and red meat are fine to turn often when on high 
heat.  Doing this will cool the cooking side avoiding charring. At the same 
time the movement will not allow too much heat to penetrate the middle so 
it cooks slower towards the middle.  You will end up with a highly 
"crusted" not burned, meat that if seasoned well will be amazing.  However, 
delicate meats like salmon and white fish would be risky as it can lose its 
integrity and fall apart when flipping.
comments.author: douglasrmarion

comments.text:
Fully cooking very high end tuna would ruin the product. It wouldn't be 
worth spending the money at that point on it. It would be like cooking a 
Wagyu Ribeye well done.
comments.author: Jamiesyme999

comments.text: +norcatch I see. Thanks!
comments.author: Akif Oblong

comments.text:
+Akif Oblong
That's always a matter of taste. I would turn it frequently, as often as 
every fifteen seconds. That will help avoid the outside being carbonized. 
You can also just cook it on a lower heat, but with choice cuts of meat (or 
tunafish), fast and hot generally work better than low and slow.

Low and slow, on the other hand, works great for tougher cuts, either 
stewed or roasted.
comments.author: norcatch

comments.text:
+norcatch I still hasn't develop the taste for anything rare or medium. Do 
you have any idea how to cook this fish without the outside turning into 
coal? Should I turn down the heat on the pan? I'm new to cooking so please 
bear with me.
comments.author: Akif Oblong

comments.text:
That's not necessarily a bad thing. The less cooked any meat or fish is, 
the more moisture and flavour it retains. Some meats, like chicken, have a 
very real chance of infecting you with bacteria if not cooked properly, 
which is why you always have to cook chicken through. It's also why chicken 
can be a tricky meat to get right, since a minute extra on the head could 
potentially overcook it, and make it dry.

You also have to cook through any meat that has been minced, since the 
mincing will distribute bacteria through the mix. With whole cuts of red 
meat, the bacteria you need to worry about is on the outside, and browning 
the meat will kill those off, while the inside won't be a problem. I'm 
talking about fresh, well handled meat, but that goes without saying.

captions.text:
Lovely people, we're gonna do how to
cook the Perfect Tuna Steak
Two very, very different tasting basic ways to cook a Tuna Steak
The pan seared is really delicious, more caramalised
the charred is much more nutty and its got that little bitter edge that works really will with
the lemon juice and the sweetness of the Tuna
I want to cook both, so you can make your own mind up

which, which one you think my fancy. Look
at that, absolutely gorgeous!
this is from the Maldives it's line caught, so very sustainable
but it is important when we're buying fish, not just to buy the freshest

and the best, you do want to make sure
that you're not wrecking the sea at the same time

In England we have MSC approved, which
has a little logo that looks like that

but in every country it's slightly different so
do a little bit of Google research
and you'll find out
Get yourself a nice sharp, long knife. Thickness wise, if I was to cut it like this

It's just gonna cook so quickly it's gonna
be overcooked
If you go to the Mediterranean
Spain, Italy, France they never overcook their Tuna... they never do
You can have this raw, you can have this as a carpaccio, you can have it as a tartar
I wanna go for a minimum of a two centremetre thickness slice
So I'm gonna slice nice long movements, don't sort of jig it about
It's very easy to cut
What we're gonna do here is just put our steaks to the side and I'm going to do a little rub
It's very, very simple. I get a little teaspoon of coriander seeds
A good pinch of salt
Two of those...a pinch of fennel seeds, absolutely beautiful
and a seedy flavour. The coriander seeds are more sort of savoury... and pepper
So we're just gonna pound that up
Cracking it, smashing it
You don't have to get it super fine either
So it doesn't take much time to get to that, which is lovely
and if you taste it, it's just a lovely quite balanced seasoning
Just season the board...pick up your steak
and just plop it onto it like that
This kind of basic seasoning gives a little crust and flavouring to the Tuna which is just divine.
Very subtle. Now all I would do now is a tiny little massage up of olive oil
Just a little pat around the edges
Just like that
Here we have got a bunch of pans that are very hot. This is medium high
this is super high. They're both pre-heated.
I want it frying, I want it searing, I want it charring.. ok
So we aint mucking about. So first up I'm going to put the Tuna into the pan
Nice non-stick pan. Second up...
we're gonna go onto the griddle pan and just touch it and push it down so it's fully in contact
With the bars
A really important thing to mention here guys

always with a griddle pan never put oil
in it... ever. Never, ever, ever.
Right? you want it screaming hot, you want it dry
If we look into the pans, you can see

the effect of the heat on the fish and
you need to sort of recognise that, that is the speed

in which the heat is travelling through the
fish
now remember we do not want to cook this
all the way through. So look it's had about a minute and a half...two minutes max

We're gonna go to the charred one first.
Look at that, beautiful.

Back in the pan. Let's go over now to the
other pan
Right now it's seared, we can just put a little oil in here
just to really get it absolutely gorgeous.
I've just done about a minute and a half on each side. This Tune is cooked. This is a nice opportunity
just to drizzle in good oil again. Any meat or fish that comes off the grill

or off the oven you know is gonna start
to wanna really dry up
Ok so a little drizzle is always good. I'm letting this Tuna just rest for a minute

also I'm just gonna have a little lemon
to protect the fish
and to season it as well
That, if you look into the heart of that. So we're just gonna tear it and I like to tear it, not slice it
That's what I would call perfect
I'm going to do exactly the same thing again with the seared one
We've got that lovely caramelised sort of cap and you get that from the contact of the pan
We're gonna tear that open again, absolutely gorgeous.
So there you go lovely people, two beautiful ways
to cook a Tuna steak.
Of course if you want to cook it more, please do
but I wouldn't advise. This Tuna is so gorgeous, is so meaty, it's so delicate
very delicious as well. I'm serving this today with a beautiful mixed tomato salad
If you want to know how to make the perfect tomato salad
Then just click on the link over here and you can go through to my new video
Take care guys, lots of love. Until next time
Bye!
Keep the comments coming in. We love reading your comments. If you like this video, then share this on your social media
because that's what it's all here for
and remember if you haven't subscribed, it's free, just press that button, go on, up there...press it! Yeah.

title: How to Cook Tuna Steak | Jamie Oliver
